<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_softirq_dispatch:
```c
void metal_softirq_dispatch(void)
{
	int i;

	for (i = 0; i < metal_softirq_num; i++) {
		struct metal_irq *irq;
		char is_pending = 1;

		if (atomic_load(&metal_softirq_enabled[i]) != 0 &&
		    atomic_compare_exchange_strong(&metal_softirq_pending[i],
						   &is_pending, 0)) {
			irq = &metal_softirqs[i];
			(void)metal_irq_handle(irq,
					       i + metal_softirq_cntr.irq_base);
		}
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_softirq_dispatch:

...

...

...

...
static METAL_IRQ_CONTROLLER_DECLARE(metal_softirq_cntr,
				    METAL_IRQ_ANY, METAL_SOFTIRQ_NUM,
				    NULL,
				    metal_softirq_set_enable, NULL,
				    metal_softirqs)
...
struct metal_irq {
	metal_irq_handler hd; /**< Interrupt handler */
	void *arg; /**< Argument to pass to the interrupt handler */
}
...
int irq_base
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
(void)metal_irq_handle(irq, i + metal_softirq_cntr.irq_base);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown fragment: the expression i + metal_softirq_cntr.irq_base computes and passes an rvalue (an int) to metal_irq_handle; it does not modify either i or metal_softirq_cntr.irq_base. This call site does not violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. (A possible violation scenario would be if metal_irq_handle were declared to take a pointer and the call passed &metal_softirq_cntr.irq_base, or if metal_irq_handle itself modified its parameter inside its body — that internal modification of a parameter would violate 17.8.)
